title: Juan Manuel Azconzábal
text:
Juan Manuel Azconzábal (born 8 September 1974 in <a href="Jun%C3%ADn%2C%20Buenos%20Aires">Junín</a>, <a href="Buenos%20Aires%20Province">Buenos Aires</a>) is an <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> coach and former <a href="defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a> who played professional football for ten clubs in six countries. He is the current manager of <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Tucum%C3%A1n">Atlético Tucumán</a>.
Career.
Azconzábal made his debut with Estudiantes de La Plata in 1994, and played for the club until 2002. That year, Azconzábal moved to Mexico to play for <a href="Tecos%20UAG">Tecos</a>. he returned to Argentina in 2003 to play for <a href="Chacarita%20Juniors">Chacarita Juniors</a>. Azconzábal then played for <a href="Universitario%20de%20Deportes">Universitario</a> in <a href="Peru">Peru</a> and <a href="Club%20Sport%20Emelec">Emelec</a> in <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> before returning to Argentina to play for> <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Banfield">Banfield</a>. In 2006, he moved to <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a> to play for <a href="Independiente%20Medell%C3%ADn">Independiente Medellín</a> but returned once again to Argentina later that year to sign for <a href="Rosario%20Central">Rosario Central</a>. After a short stint in the Canary Islands with <a href="UD%20Las%20Palmas">Las Palmas</a>, he signed for <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Tucum%C3%A1n">Club Atlético Tucumán</a>.
After his retirement, Azconzábal was signed by Estudiantes as manager of football operations. Upon the resignation of <a href="Miguel%20Angel%20Russo">Miguel Angel Russo</a> on 7 November 2011, Azconzábal was named caretaker coach, and after a string of good results he was appointed as coach for the 2012 Clausura tournament.
Azconzábal's nickname is "el vasco" (the <a href="Basque%20people">Basque</a>), as his surname is of Basque origin.
